content.rendered:
This is a common question and it is often based on a fundamental misunderstanding. The truth is – There are no special foodstuffs. There is no assortment of foods are the key to your weight gain/loss or otherwise achieving your goals. You can’t go to the grocery store and load up on X and have that be the miracle that gets you over your hurdles. That meal plan the Instagram bodybuilder or personal trainer at your gym wants to sell you doesn’t have anything secret or special in it.

As long as you aren’t eating like an asshole, specific foods will have no noticeable impact, so don’t buy into fads about “superfoods” and other such nonsense. Tailor your calorie and macronutrient consumption to your goals. Within reason, eat foods that you like. If you need more of a specific macronutrient, eat more of any foods that have a higher density of it. If you don’t know of foods that meet specific criteria, just use Google – because answering questions like that is something Google excels at.

For good guidelines on generally improving your diet, have a look at – General Diet Improvement.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Improving Your Diet
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Before we get into the details, there is one thing above all else that it is important to grasp if you want results that last. You must be willing to treat this as a change to your lifestyle. If your intent is to "go on a diet" until you reach…

jetpack-related-posts.title: What should I do to have a healthy diet?
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: In terms of what foods you should and should not eat, remember that calories matter more than specific foods. Adequate macro- and micro-nutrition are indeed part of a healthy diet, but appropriate caloric intake is by far the most important rule regardless of the source and whether or not the food…

jetpack-related-posts.title: Muscle Building 101
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Introduction There is an illusion of complexity to gaining weight and building muscle (perpetuated largely by people who want your money) but it is actually very straightforward. Your body requires a certain amount of energy (measured in calories) each day in order to fuel its activities. This is called your…

jetpack-related-posts.title: Is my meal plan any good?
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: As long as it meets your calorie and macronutrient needs and doesn't look like it was put together by a five-to-sixteen year old whose parents are out of town, your meal plan is fine. Specific food choices make no noticeable difference provided you aren't just stuffing your face with junk…

jetpack-related-posts.title: Community Campfires
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: The r/Fitness Community Campfire threads are for users who have had success in overcoming a specific kind of challenge for their fitness to share their experience with the community (as one might share tales of victory around a campfire) of what worked for them, and answer questions that anyone might…

jetpack-related-posts.title: Why can't I gain weight?
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: If you are not gaining weight, you are not eating enough and are not reaching a calorie surplus. You must eat more. It doesn't matter how much you think you're eating. It doesn't matter what your TDEE calculator says. It doesn't matter what your food logs say. If you're not…
